name: Dengue
question: What is Dengue?
Overview: Dengue is a viral disease. It is transmitted by the infective bite of Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes. These mosquitoes also spread Zika, Chikungunya, and other diseases. Man develops disease after 5-6 days of being bitten by an infective mosquito. Infected person with Dengue becomes infective to mosquitoes 6 to 12 hours before the onset of the disease and remains so upto 3 to 5 days.Dengue is caused by one of any of four related viruses: Dengue virus 1, 2, 3, and 4.  A person can be infected with dengue multiple times in their life.
type1: Dengue Fever: Dengue Fever is a flu-like illness
type2: Dengue Haemorrhagic Fever (DHF): Dengue Haemorrhagic Fever (DHF) is a more severe form of disease, which may cause death. Person suspected of having dengue fever or DHF must attend the nearest medical facility.
fact1: Almost half of the world’s population, about 4 billion people, live in areas with a risk of dengue. Dengue is often a leading cause of illness in areas with risk.
fact2: Each year, up to 400 million people are infected by a dengue virus.
fact3: Approximately 100 million people get sick from infection, and 40,000 die from severe dengue.
measure1description: Use of mosquito repellent creams, liquids, coils, mats etc. Wearing of full sleeve shirts and full pants with socks. Use of bed nets for sleeping infants and young children during day time to prevent mosquito bite.
measure2description: Use of larvivorous fishes in ornamental tanks, fountains, etc.
measure3description: Use of chemical larvicides like Temephos 50% EC in big water holdings. Aerosol space spray during day time in and around the houses, market places, large campuses and buildings using Pyrethrum 2% Extract.
measure4description: Identification and destruction of mosquito breeding sources. Management of roof tops, porticos and sunshades. The water storing containers should be scrubbed and washed with bleaching powder every week. They should be properly covered with a cloth or sheet so as to prevent mosquito breeding in the water containers. Reliable water supply. Observation of weekly dry day.
measure5description: Impart knowledge to common people regarding the disease and vector through various media sources like T.V., Radio, Cinema slides, etc.
measure6title: Dengue Fever mobile App in Tamil
measure6description: The Dengue Fever Mobile App can be downloaded from Google Play Store. Dengue Fever Tamil App provides complete pictorial information about the sources where Aedes mosquitoes breed along with an exhaustive Frequently Asked Questions. Information on effective siddha treatment is made available.
measure7description: Sensitizing and involving the community for detection of Aedes breeding places and their elimination.
risk1: Mosquito Exposure: Being in areas where mosquitoes that carry the dengue virus are present increases the risk.
risk2: Travel: Traveling to regions where dengue is endemic or epidemic exposes individuals to the virus.
risk3: Lack of Vector Control: Poor mosquito control measures in urban or rural areas can lead to higher mosquito populations and thus increase the risk of dengue transmission.
risk4: Standing Water: Accumulation of stagnant water in containers or areas around homes provides breeding grounds for mosquitoes that transmit the virus.
risk5: Climate Factors: Weather conditions such as heavy rainfall followed by periods of drought can create environments conducive to mosquito breeding and dengue transmission.
risk6: Poor Sanitation: Inadequate waste management and sanitation practices can contribute to the proliferation of mosquitoes.
risk7: Individual Susceptibility: Factors such as age, immunity, and overall health status can influence an individual's susceptibility to dengue infection.

ayush1.title: Papaya Leaf Juice
ayush1.description: Fresh Papaya leaves (excluding veins) should be mixed with a little cold water and ground and filtered. Consume 10 ml four times a day. Fever will subside on consumption for five days. Even after recovery from fever this may be continued for another two days. Papaya leaf juice is a traditional homemade natural medicine.

ayush2.title: Malai Vembu Leaf (Hill Neem) Juice
ayush2.description: Fresh Malaivembu leaves should be mixed with a little cold water and ground and filtered. Consume 10 ml two to three times a day. Fever will subside on consumption for five days. Even after recovery from fever this may be continued for another two days. Malaivembu leaf juice is a traditional homemade natural medicine.

ayush3.title: Nilavembu Kudineer
ayush3.description: Boil 10 grams of Nilavembu Kudineer Powder in 100 ml of water until it gets reduced to half and consume 50 ml two times per day in the morning and evening. Prepare the Nilavembu Kudineer freshly for each dose. Fever will subside on consumption for five days. Even after recovery from fever this may be continued for another two days. Nilavembu Kudineer powder is available in all Siddha wings in Government Hospitals and Primary Health Centres free of cost.

name: Chikungunya
question: What is Chikungunya?
Overview: Chikungunya virus is spread to people by the bite of an infected mosquito. The most common symptoms of infection are fever and joint pain. Other symptoms may include headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, or rash. Outbreaks have occurred in countries in Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe, and the Caribbean, Indian and Pacific Oceans. There is a risk the virus will be spread to unaffected areas by infected travelers. There is currently no medicine to treat chikungunya virus infection.
transmission: Chikungunya virus is transmitted by mosquitoes, most commonly Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti and Aedes (Stegomyia) albopictus, which can also transmit dengue and Zika viruses. These mosquitoes bite primarily during daylight hours. They lay eggs in containers with standing water. Both species feed outdoors, and Aedes aegypti also feeds indoors. When an uninfected mosquito feeds on a person who has CHIKV circulating in their blood, the mosquito can ingest the virus. The virus then replicates in the mosquito over several days, gets to its salivary glands, and can be transmitted into a new human host when the mosquito bites them. The virus again begins to replicate in this newly infected person and reaches high concentrations in their blood, at which point they can further infect other mosquitoes and perpetuate the transmission cycle
measure1description: No vaccine or medication is available to prevent chikungunya virus infection or disease. Reduce mosquito exposure by Using air conditioning or window/door screens, using mosquito repellents on exposed skin, wearing long-sleeved shirts and long pants, wearing permethrin-treated clothing. Empty standing water from outdoor containers. People suspected to have chikungunya or dengue should be protected from further mosquito exposure during the first week of illness to reduce the risk of further transmission. People at increased risk for severe disease should consider not traveling to areas with ongoing chikungunya outbreak.
risk1: Mosquito Exposure: Being in areas where Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, are present increases the risk of chikungunya virus transmission.
risk2: Travel: Traveling to regions where chikungunya is endemic or experiencing outbreaks increases the risk of exposure to the virus.
risk3: Outdoor Activities: Spending time outdoors, especially during periods of peak mosquito activity, increases the likelihood of being bitten by infected mosquitoes.
risk4: Lack of Personal Protection Measures: Not using mosquito repellent, wearing long-sleeved clothing, or sleeping under mosquito nets in endemic areas increases the risk of mosquito bites.
risk5: Urban Settings: Urban environments with dense populations and inadequate mosquito control measures can facilitate the spread of chikungunya virus.
risk6: Climate Factors: Weather conditions such as high temperatures and rainfall can influence mosquito populations and their activity, affecting the risk of chikungunya transmission.
risk7: Age and Health Status: While people of all ages can be infected, older adults and individuals with weakened immune systems may be at higher risk of developing severe symptoms.
risk8: Previous Exposure: Previous infection with chikungunya virus can confer immunity to subsequent infections, reducing the risk of reinfection and severe illness. However, individuals who have not been previously exposed are more susceptible to infection.

ayush1.title: Ayurveda
ayush1.description: Chikungunya treatments people are majorly depending upon ayurveda. Chikungunya have another name in ayurveda which is known as sandhijwara (fever of joints). It is considered as vata dosha disorder. The herbs such as sacred basil (tulsi), carrot, grapes are usual recommended as relief for the pain and fever. Ayurvedic massage also done for the relief of joint pain. The treatment recommends the patients: To increase the intake of fluid containing foods and vegetables, Reduce the use of oil, Avoid the intake of tea and coffee.

ayush2.title: Homeopathy
ayush2.description: Nowadays effective medicines are available in homeopathy for the treatment of chikungunya which possess speed recovery. Some of the medicines are: Eupatorium-perf Pyroginum, Rhustos, Arnica, Bryonia.

ayush3.title: Siddha
ayush3.description: For chikungunya medicines are available in siddha. Some of them are: Nilavenbu kudineer mixture, Pinda thailam, Karpooraadhi thailam.

name: Malaria
question: What is Malaria?
Overview: Malaria is a serious disease caused by a parasite that infects a certain type of mosquito. Most people get malaria from the bite of an infective mosquito. Malaria can be a deadly disease if not diagnosed and treated quickly. Starting treatment as soon as possible can often prevent severe illness and death. There are 4 types of malarial parasites namely Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium falciparum, Plasmodium malaria and Plasmodium ovale.
transmission: Malaria is transmitted through the bite of an infective Anopheles mosquito. These mosquitoes typically bite between dusk and dawn. The parasites multiply in the liver and then infect red blood cells, causing symptoms. Traveling to endemic areas, mosquito exposure, lack of personal protection measures, time of outdoor activity, living conditions, immune status, healthcare access, and drug resistance are all factors contributing to the transmission of malaria.
measure1description: Early diagnosis of fever and taking complete radical treatment will prevent transmission of malaria parasites. Wear loose-fitting, long-sleeved shirts and pants. Keep windows and doors closed or covered with screens to keep mosquitoes out of your house. Empty standing water at least once a week to prevent mosquitoes from laying eggs.
measure2description: Larval source management by mosquito breeding source reduction and application of Temephos in breeding sources.
measure4description: Identification and destruction of mosquito breeding sources. Management of roof tops, porticos, and sunshades. The water storing containers should be scrubbed and washed with bleaching powder every week. They should be properly covered with a cloth or sheet so as to prevent mosquito breeding in the water containers. Reliable water supply. Observation of weekly dry day.
measure5description: Impart knowledge to common people regarding the disease and vector through various media sources like T.V., Radio, Cinema slides, etc.
risk1: Travel to Endemic Areas: Traveling to regions where malaria is prevalent increases the risk of exposure to the parasite.
risk2: Mosquito Exposure: Being in areas where Anopheles mosquitoes, the vectors for malaria, are present increases the risk of transmission.
risk3: Lack of Personal Protection Measures: Not using mosquito repellent, bed nets, or wearing protective clothing in endemic areas increases the risk of mosquito bites.
risk4: Time of Outdoor Activity: Being outdoors during peak mosquito biting times (dusk and dawn) increases the risk of being bitten.
risk5: Living Conditions: Living in or near areas with poor sanitation, inadequate housing, and standing water increases the risk of mosquito breeding and malaria transmission.
risk6: Immune Status: Individuals with weakened immune systems, such as young children, pregnant women, and individuals with HIV/AIDS, are at higher risk of developing severe malaria if infected.
risk7: Healthcare Access: Limited access to healthcare facilities for diagnosis and treatment can delay appropriate management of malaria, increasing the risk of severe complications.
risk8: Drug Resistance: Resistance of the malaria parasite to antimalarial drugs can make treatment less effective, leading to prolonged illness and increased risk of complications.

ayush1.title: Mahasudarshan Churna, Tribhuvan kirti & Parijat vati
ayush1.description: Ayurveda has proven medicines to treat malaria viz. Mahasudarshan Churna, Tribhuvan kirti & Parijat vati, which treat “Visham jwara” its Ayurvedic indication.

ayush2.title: Neem, Kalmegh & Harsingar
ayush2.description: Folk medicines reported, but rarely, to treat malaria include Neem, Kalmegh & Harsingar, where in a clinical study in Mumbai on 120 Malaria patients, 77% showed complete parasite eradication within 7 days of treatment with the leaf paste, and is also found safe.

ayush3.title: Ayush 64
ayush3.description: Ayush 64 is a polyherbal formulation developed by the Central Council for Research in Ayurvedic Science in the year 1980, for Malaria. Based on many clinical studies found that effective in asymptomatic, mild, and moderate COVID-19 infections as an adjunct to standard care. It is a combination of four Ayurvedic drugs; Alstonia scholaris, Picrorhiza kurroa, Swertia chirata, and Caesalpinia crista: the active ingredients showed notable antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antipyretic properties: that enables relief from cough, cold and joint pain. And also significantly reduce the duration of clinical recovery in terms of disease symptoms and severity.
